destination.label: Mexico
destination.title: Mexico City: a bustling capital of history, art, and celebration

content.intro:
Once the centre of Aztec civilisation, Mexico City is now the cultural, financial, and political capital of Mexico. A megalopolis with almost 9 million inhabitants in the city proper, this is a place that never sleeps.

With its green parks, colonial palaces, and world-class museums, Mexico offers endless options for urban adventurers, art lovers, and those who are simply curious about the world. Mexico City was founded by Spanish conquistadors in 1525 on the ruins of the ancient Aztec city of Tenochtitlan. With this rich and eventful history, it is an ideal destination for anyone wishing to discover the history of the country. Its city centre, a UNESCO World Heritage site, is an enjoyable journey through buildings steeped in history, like El Zócalo (otherwise known as ‘Plaza de la Constitución'), the largest square in the city. Bordered on one side by the National Palace, which houses the offices of the Mexican President, the Treasury, and the National Archives, and on the other by the Metropolitan Cathedral (its full name: Catedral Metropolitana de la Asunción de María Catedral Metropolitana de México), a vestige of the colonial era, this is where the country's main events take place. Get lost in the city, stroll through Chapultepec Park, as do all families on Sunday, and look up to see the palm trees and all the riches of the city.
Finally, Mexico City is enchanting for artists, who come here to visit the home of the famous painter Frida Kahlo or to visit the museum of modern art. Glide through the canals of Xochimilco aboard a trajinera, a flowery and colourful boat on which you can eat tortillas, tacos, enchiladas, quesadillas, and other delicacies.
But the discovery of the city would not be complete without a visit to the famous Basilica of Our Lady of Guadalupe, which annually welcomes millions of pilgrims who come to pray where the Virgin Mary was said to have appeared to a shepherd in the 16th century.

content.title: Colours, costumes and chocolate in Oaxaca

introduction.small: To the south-east of hectic Mexico City, Oaxaca de Juárez charms as much with its architectural treasures – it is a UNESCO World Heritage Site – as with its gentle way of life.

paragraphs.text:
Getting to the heart of history

A six-hour drive south-east of Mexico City, Oaxaca, or Oaxaca de Juárez as it is sometimes called, is full of charm. It does not take long to fall for its colourful streets and markets, the plethora of colonial-era monuments and, of course, its unique archaeological treasures. It proves to be the perfect place for those who simply like to take their time and enjoy a cultural and gourmet break. So, take advantage of the mild temperatures between November and January to get to know this mythical city.

As you wander around the streets of Oaxaca, and especially down the famous pedestrianised Calle Alcalá, do not miss the Santo Domingo Cultural Centre. Santo Domingo de Guzmán church is part of this huge architectural complex. Flanked by two 35 metre high towers, each crowned with a cupola made of blue and white ceramic tiles, it is a symbol of its own importance. When you step through the door, you are struck by the contrast between the simple facade outside and the splendid, exuberant Mexican Baroque style inside. You will not manage to count them all, but almost 60,000 pieces of gold leaf were used inside the church! Then, look up at the ceiling in the nave to see 36 paintings representing scenes from the Old Testament. This building, constructed in the 16th century, has had a glorious past; for a time, it was the most imposing religious complex in Mexico, comprising a Dominican convent, vast gardens and umpteen patios. Paying due respect to its past grandeur, an extensive renovation campaign got underway back in 1993.

Today, you can also visit the Francisco de Burgoa library with works dating from the 15th to 20th centuries. Do not forget to take a walk in the Ethnobotanical Garden: the collection of Mexican plants and cacti is simply wonderful. Finally, put time aside to visit the Museum of Oaxacan Cultures. This is where Zapotec treasures discovered in the archaeological sites of Monte Albán are displayed, the highlight being the superb Mixtec stash from Tomb 7, discovered in 1932. It provides a fascinating journey to the very heart of pre-Hispanic civilisations.

Santo Domingo Cultural Centre
Macedonio Alcalá s/n
68000 Oaxaca de Juárez
Mexico
+52 (951) 516 9741
https://www.facebook.com/pg/Centro-Cultural-Santo-Domingo-177190954302/about/?ref=page_internal

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

A taste for celebration

You stroll along cobbled streets, admire trees in full bloom, see colourful buildings with thick walls. Everything seems so quiet and peaceful… Then suddenly, you come across a small group of people dressed in fabulous traditional costumes as brightly coloured as the walls of their homes. Here, the locals love to put on a show to express their happiness and pride when celebrating an important family event, such as a wedding or christening.

If you are staying in Oaxaca over the Christmas period, something festive will be going on almost every day. The oaxaqueños share the joy of Advent by decorating the streets and meeting up in the evening in the city centre decked out with Christmas lights. As the children are on holiday at this time of year, there is even more of a party atmosphere.

After these lively nights out on the town, you come back to the peaceful surroundings of your hotel, the Casa Oaxaca, located a stone's throw from the Zócalo. This boutique hotel, with just seven rooms, occupies a beautiful 18th-century colonial residence which has been completely renovated and decorated to create an uncluttered, contemporary feel. You will love the contrast of vibrant colours, the carefully selected works by local artists and the central patio, a typical feature of these houses, profusely decorated with pots of cacti cleverly placed here and there. It is perfect for reading a book, having breakfast or just relaxing, unless, of course, you prefer one of the hammocks up on the roof terrace. From there, the view over the two towers of neighbouring Santo Domingo church is superb.

Casa Oaxaca
Calle de Manuel García Vigil 407
68000 Oaxaca de Juárez
Mexico
+52 (951) 514 4173
https://casaoaxaca.com.mx

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Oaxaca's gourmet treasure

The city is also home to a treasure of quite a different kind which you are just going to love. Legend has it that the best hot chocolate in the world is right here in Oaxaca. It is true that Mexico is the historic birthplace of cocoa. The Aztecs knew how to enjoy the tasty qualities of the famous bean with its slight hint of bitterness, long before the arrival of the Europeans led by Hernán Cortés. Most often, it is cultivated in Chiapas and then brought to Oaxaca for roasting. Calling chocoholics of all ages… head to Calle Mina where you will find Mayordomo, La Soledad and Guelaguetza chocolate shops. Here, chocolate is everywhere in all its forms: as chips, it melts delicately in your mouth; as squares, you bite into it with a big crunch; as powder, it is mixed with boiling water or milk for a marvellous chocolatey drink. Our advice is to ask for almonds, vanilla or even cinnamon to be added to your preparation, in place of the original chilli pepper. In that way, you walk out with your own customised chocolate! You can also opt for artisan chocolate made in one of the many workshops, such as Fantasía en Chocolate in Calle Xicoténcatl.

For a fitting end to your gourmet break, make your way to Benito Juárez market. Once there, head to La Toñita. A frothy hot chocolate arrives just the way you like it, giving off a delicious aroma. Quiet please, we are savouring the moment… Do you want to recreate the same ‘moustache' effect when you get back home? Then consider buying a molinillo, a wooden utensil that whisks up that famous frothy creaminess. If you have a bit of time to spare, wander up and down the aisles of the market; you will find local crafts and also some very tasty specialities, such as quesillo (string cheese) and tasajo (dried beef). The more adventurous among you might even like to try chapulines (grasshoppers)!

content.title: Meroma, Mexican expertise in the highlight

introduction.small: Meroma's modern and creative cuisine counts on small local producers and brings out Mexican skills.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Meroma, Mexican expertise in the highlight

paragraphs.text:
In one of Mexico City's most emblematic streets, in the heart of the Roma Norte neighbourhood, a large retro house from the 1970s with oval windows shelters Meroma. This contemporary Mexican restaurant, split on two levels, brings out a sense of aesthetics, reminiscing of the 1950s New York City as seen in the Mad Men series. On the ground floor, the cocktail bar welcomes gourmets before they head upstairs to discover the menu.
From the decoration to the food in your plate, Meroma showcases Mexican skills. The architecture has been conceived by a famous Mexico agency – the terrace covered with a glass dome being of special interest. The homemade dishware was supplied by a local craftsman, and the restaurant calls upon suppliers working in sustainable farming, the chinampas (cultivable land created on lacustrine areas) as well as local farms and small producers. Dishes are all prepared using products from the nearby regions, like the foie gras served with rhubarb, strawberries and cherries. As for the goat cheese pie, it comes with rice pudding and camomile. There, the goal is to let you experience totally new flavours and combinations!

Meroma
Colima 150
Roma Norte
06700 Ciudad de México, D.F.

+52 55 5920 2654

www.meroma.mx

Menu: around 535 MXN

content.title: LUR, when Basque gastronomy meets Mexican cuisine

introduction.small: In Mexico City's Polanco neighbourhood, LUR creates a casual chic environment for you to enjoy its specialities inspired by two different regions: Mexico and the French Basque Country.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: LUR, when Basque gastronomy meets Mexican cuisine

paragraphs.text:
Earth-linked elements are everywhere to be found in this restaurant that showcases a plant-based decoration. Which is hardly surprising, considering the name of the establishment: lur means “earth” and “ground” in old Basque dialect. The furniture, wainscoting, lights and, generally speaking, wood everywhere are the stars at LUR. This soft atmosphere is being enhanced by the use of plants, spread around the tables, as well as old cement tiles and grey-blue bench seats. On the menu, Basque and Mexican inspirations come together for unique results, like duck cannelloni for starters. Fresh ingredients are always given prominence, like the catch of the day, cooked with artichokes, calamari and red hot peppers. Whether in the decoration or in your plate, LUR focuses on perfectly highlighted raw products.

LUR

Polanco

www.restaurantelur.com/en/

Menu: around 495 MXN

content.title: A flowery table and colourful dishes at Dulce Patria

introduction.small: Sample Dulce Patria's all-female gastronomy where 100% creative dishes have been specially developed for you.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: A flowery table and colourful dishes at Dulce Patria

paragraphs.text:
On two floors, each with its own terrace, take the time to settle into a setting dominated by pink and red: you will soon discover the menu of chef Martha Ortiz for a memorable culinary moment.

Here you will enjoy the most modern cuisine that still holds dear time-tested artisanal cooking techniques. In the middle of multi-coloured flowers, a wide range of dishes, each as creative as the next, and Mexican influences, you will be served with the pleasure of the eyes and senses. For the savoury dishes, you will have the choice between ceviches, tostadas and the famous mole poblano (Mexican speciality using a multi-spice sauce) and for a sweeter touch, do not miss the carousel of desserts garnished with Mexican candies and chocolates. Once the dessert is finished, alegrías (candies) will be brought to you in a miniature wooden airplane.

content.title: Ballet Folklórico de México, time to dance

introduction.small: Founded by Amalia Hernández in 1952, Mexico's Folkloric Ballet has moved millions of spectators so far, showing an unknown side of the country to the public.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Ballet Folklórico de México, time to dance

paragraphs.text:
2017 celebrated the centennial of talented Mexican dancer and choreographer Amalia Hernández's birthday. Get ready for the colourful traditional costumes, astounding musical landscapes and magnetic movements of the company! For 6 decades now, the Ballet Folklórico de México has offered shows mixing culture and dance over catchy rhythms.
You will discover the country's beautiful cultural diversity amid the gorgeous Palace of Fine Arts, showcasing Carrara marble, Tiffany circular stained-glass and Diego Rivera and Rufino Tamayo's frescoes among others. A company of international fame will take you on a trip through Mexico's territories. From the Maya civilization to cow-boys, the shows shine a light on the country's different populations, with high quality and standards levels.

content.title: Contemporary art is within reach at the Tamayo Museum

introduction.small: Settled into the Chapultepec Woods, the Tamayo Museum comes emerges from the soil like a pre-Hispanic pyramid that shelters treasures of contemporary art at its heart.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Contemporary art is within reach at the Tamayo Museum

paragraphs.text:
Before founding the museum in 1981, artist Rufino Tamayo and his wife Olga spent close to ten years acquiring contemporary works. Created by Abraham Zabludovsky and Teodoro González de Léon, the architecture itself has been thought of like an additional work of art for the collection – a stunning object in its own right. Made of white marble and glass, the building is perfectly integrated into the history of the city by recalling the form of pre-Colombian era pyramids. Inside, the works are struck either by natural or artificial light, creating different ambiances.
Stroll through this magnificent pyramid and admire the works of major artists such as Miró, Picasso, Bacon, Botero, Warhol and Lichtenstein. On your way out, take a walk through the Chapultepec Woods and make the most of its lakes, fountains and magnificent monuments.

Museo Tamayo

content.title: Arroyo: one of the biggest restaurants in the world

introduction.small: With seating for up to 2,200 patrons, Arroyo, in lively Tlalpan, is not to be missed.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Arroyo: one of the biggest restaurants in the world

paragraphs.text:
Under high ceilings covered with colourful Mexican motifs, the Arroyo restaurant spans nine indoor and outdoor dining rooms, making it ideal for large-scale fiestas. On stage and among the tables, the mariachis play and sing the most typical Mexican tunes with emotion. The restaurant even has its own arena for cockfighting. The long communal tables are filled with locals who come with their families to celebrate and watch Arroyo's hearty cuisine being prepared by women dressed in traditional clothes.

Discover pre-Columbian flavours, like slow-cooked roast mutton or, for the less timid, soft ant larvae. Among contemporary Mexican dishes, try a thick tortilla, called a sope, stuffed with refried beans, chicken, lettuce, and cheese, or roasted meats accompanied by generous servings of stewed cactus and corn tortillas.

content.title: Hotel Habita: a trendy boutique hotel

introduction.small: Luxurious and visionary, Habita has revolutionised the hotel scene in Mexico.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hotel Habita: a trendy boutique hotel

paragraphs.text:
The epitome of cool, urban boutique hotels, Hotel Habita is located in a 1950s building that has been turned into a glass cube in very upscale Polanco. The hotel's avant-garde design is in a minimalist style, accented with natural wood.

The 32 rooms and four modern suites are kitted out with Eames furniture and oversized bathtubs. Some rooms even have full-length balconies. Nestled on the roof, La Terraza is one of Mexico City's outdoor bars, an ideal spot for savouring a cocktail and the panoramic view of the city.

The hotel also has a spa, a gym, a solarium, and a library. On the ground floor, Bistro, the hotel's restaurant, serves modern Mexican cuisine in a retro-chic decor.

content.title: Danubio: a cantina for regulars

introduction.small: An unpretentious seafood restaurant that, nonetheless, attracts politicians and celebrities.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Danubio: a cantina for regulars

paragraphs.text:
Time flows in this venerable institution in the historic centre of Mexico without seeming to leave the smallest footprint. Originally opened in 1936 by immigrants from the Basque Country, the influence of Basque cuisine has remained strong throughout the years.

You will love the vintage pictures in their gilt frames, white tablecloths on the tables, autographed napkins that adorn the walls, and also a timeless ambiance that is so much the charm of the place.

Enjoy house specialties, like langoustines, lobster Thermidor, oysters au gratin, and crab ceviche. Each dish, ultra-fresh, is prepared only to order. Let yourself be tempted by the wine list, which focuses on Spanish wines.

content.title: Contramar: an institution

introduction.small: The place to go for lovers of fish and seafood.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Contramar: an institution

paragraphs.text:
Contramar, in the Roma district, is a veritable institution in Mexico City. Families come to feast on crab tacos, shellfish soups, and grilled fish. With its marine-motif murals and large open kitchen, the restaurant was famous before the area became fashionable in recent years.

Enjoy a pescado a la talla, the restaurant's speciality: fresh fish served whole, barely grilled and served with black beans and a homemade sauce. For dessert, indulge in coconut flan or fig tart. Please note the restaurant is only open for lunch, so you must reserve your table and allow about 30 minutes wait time.

Contramar

content.title: La N° 20 Polanco: a perfect place for a party

introduction.small: This Art Deco cantina mixes traditional music and delicious food.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: La N° 20 Polanco: a perfect place for a party

paragraphs.text:
There are always great people at No° 20 Polanco. Mexico City's crème de la crème come here, as well as politicians and show business celebrities. For starters, the music gets people dancing.

When you enter this sophisticated bar, it seems decidedly Parisian in style, with its old ballrooms and ceilings covered in Art Deco-style designs. But instantly, you will be drawn into a whirlpool of mariachis, music, and songs that will spark your soul.

In short, you will be immersed in the atmosphere of an authentic Mexican cantina. The No° 20 Polanco makes you feel like you have travelled back into the past for one memorable evening.

content.title: A day in the life of Frida Kahlo

introduction.small: Built in 1904, Casa Azul is the place where Frida Kahlo was born, where she lived, and where she died as Latin America's best-known painter.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: A day in the life of Frida Kahlo

paragraphs.text:
The vibrant colours and popular pre-Hispanic decorations of this splendid blue house bear witness to the admiration Frida Kahlo and her husband, painter Diego Rivera, had for the villages and culture of Mexico.

A museum since 1958, four years after Frida Kahlo's death, the place has retained its intimate atmosphere, thanks to Carlos Pellicer, poet and friend of the couple, who established the museum and preserved it in its natural state: the brushes, easel, books, and even letters are all there.

Strolling through every corner of this house full of photographs, personal objects, and Mexican artefacts is a way to immerse yourself in the inspirations and daily life of this couple, legends of 20th-century art history.

Museo Frida Kahlo

www.museofridakahlo.org.mx/en/

content.title: Distrito Capital: head in the sky

introduction.small: Inaugurated in 2009, the Distrito Capital hotel occupies the top five floors of a skyscraper in the suburbs of Santa Fe.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Distrito Capital: head in the sky

paragraphs.text:
French designer Joseph Dirand created a modern-style sanctuary in the Santa Fe suburbs of Mexico City, where impressive contemporary artworks stand out against black and white walls.

The 30 rooms and suites reveal high ceilings, vintage furniture, and scenic views over the rooftops of Mexico City. Everything has been thought through, including a docking station for digital music players and a video-game console.

The restaurant's chef, Enrique Olvera, serves contemporary Mexican cuisine, while the hotel bar attracts Mexico City's trendy crowd with its DJ and mezcal cocktails (drinks made with agave alcohol). A private cinema, swimming pool, outdoor lounge, solarium, and state-of-the-art fitness room are some of the luxurious amenities that will make your stay unforgettable.

content.title: Las Alcobas: luxurious and sophisticated

introduction.small: The supremely stylish Las Alcobas is an utterly exceptional boutique hotel.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Las Alcobas: luxurious and sophisticated

paragraphs.text:
New York design firm Yabu Pushelberg has created for Las Alcobas a sophisticated urban sanctuary, marrying Mexican architectural tradition with Manhattan glamour.

In black and white, the 35 spacious rooms feature rare wood, custom-designed European furnishings, and traditional Mexican decoration. Everything has been planned to ensure a memorable stay, from the selection of handmade soaps to the deep tubs, not to mention the free minibar.

The best suites even have a private terrace, a steam room, a garden, and a fireplace. For a relaxing time, enjoy a soothing massage or botanical face treatment at the Aurora Spa.

content.title: Pujol: one of the best restaurants in the world

introduction.small: A famous gastronomic restaurant merging traditional Mexican cuisine with modernity.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Pujol: one of the best restaurants in the world

paragraphs.text:
Located in the upscale neighbourhood of Polanco, Pujol is run by talented young Mexican chef Enrique Olvera. Ranked as one of the best restaurants in the world by ‘World's 50 Best Restaurants', Pujol received praise from international critics for its contemporary Mexican cuisine.

Among its most famous creations are tacos with milk-fed lamb, avocado, and puréed peas; tomato with hoja santa sauce; and fried red snapper with green mole, chives, and cuaresmeños chili peppers, as well as the barbecued ox tongue served with romerito – typical of Southern Mexico –, black beans and prickly pears. Besides the tasting menus, à la carte is also available. Do not miss the drinks menu with its well-chosen selection of wines, mescal, and tequila to accompany this unforgettable culinary journey.

Pujol
Tennyson 133
Polanco
11570 Ciudad de México, D.F.

+52 55 5545 4111

http://pujol.com.mx/en/

Tasting Menu: around 1,400 MXN

content.title: Downtown Mexico: in the heart of the Old City

introduction.small: This extremely high-end, peaceful oasis is just a few steps from the famous El Zócalo.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Downtown Mexico: in the heart of the Old City

paragraphs.text:
Downtown Mexico is a five-star hotel in the heart of the old town. Plaza de la Constitución, also known as El Zócalo, is just steps away, and the Palacio de Bellas Artes is a short stroll.

Under the arches of this boutique hotel, walkways lead to interiors designed by renowned architects Abraham Cherem and Javier Serrano. Combining contemporary materials and 17th-century architecture, the 17 rooms feature original, sober decor.

After a day of visiting museums or riding around the city on the free bicycles the hotel provides for its guests, the rooftop pool is a delight. Finish off your swim with a massage for a stay of total comfort.

content.title: W Mexico City: the first W hotel in Central and Latin America

introduction.small: W awaits you with its trendy design and atmosphere.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: W Mexico City: the first W hotel in Central and Latin America

paragraphs.text:
In the heart of upmarket Polanco, W Mexico City is surrounded by tree-lined streets, fashion boutiques and avant-garde art galleries.

Enjoy views of Polanco and Chapultepec park from 237 spacious, elegant rooms in a palette of cherry, lemon, and sapphire colours. The 29 corner suites are impressive, with the latest hi-fi systems, private dining rooms, mezzanines, and designer bathtubs. The fitness centre is open around the clock, with a spa, a sweat lodge, a kind of local sauna, and a JetStream pool. The white leather Living Room lounge becomes festive when the sun sets.

The chic Cocoa Bar is for VIP clients, while the sensual outdoor Terrace bar attracts Mexico City's trendiest folk.

content.title: Café de Tacuba: an institution since 1912

introduction.small: In a former 17th-century convent in the historic district of Centro, this café is a must.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Café de Tacuba: an institution since 1912

paragraphs.text:
With its ancient stained-glass windows, vaulted ceilings, and arches that evoke those of a Palladian villa, Café de Tacuba has the grace of the old mansions of the colonial era.

Mariachi bands and actors in medieval costumes come to serenade you at your table to the delight of tourists, businessmen, and families. In the two large dining rooms, discover all the flavours of traditional Mexican cuisine: enchiladas verdes with chicken in mole sauce, chiles rellenos, and a wide selection of tamales.

Do not miss breakfast at Café de Tacuba, with its surprising egg dishes and pastries like the honey cake, accompanied by delicious café con leche y chocolate (latte and chocolate).

content.title: JW Marriot: an irreproachable classic

introduction.small: The five-star JW Marriott epitomises elegance in upscale Polanco.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: JW Marriot: an irreproachable classic

paragraphs.text:
With comfortable living spaces and resolutely colourful design, the JW Marriott combines classic elegance and contemporary aesthetics.

The 34 rooms and suites bring together poster beds with floral motifs, delicately embroidered sheets, lacquered furniture in Queen Anne style, and beautiful marble bathrooms. The windows offer you, in turn, stunning views over the city and, in particular, Chapultepec Park. The JW Marriott has a spa, state-of-the-art fitness centre, and a heated rooftop pool with panoramic views. Dine by candlelight at Lipp, the hotel's French brasserie. Or try contemporary South American cuisine at Pergamino restaurant.

After dinner, go to the hotel's piano bar and discover one of the 100 varieties of tequila on the menu.

content.title: Four Seasons Mexico: classic luxury

introduction.small: A little gem that strictly respects Latin architecture, with a highly attentive staff.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Four Seasons Mexico: classic luxury

paragraphs.text:
Just across from the legendary Paseo de la Reforma, the Four Seasons Mexico is next to Chapultepec Park in the heart of the city.

Luxurious and relaxing, the 240 rooms and suites are decorated with period furniture. Equipped with deep soaking tubs and fine linens, they overlook either the gardens or the urban landscape of Mexico City. Relax in the hotel spa with a rejuvenating facial or a Thai massage. Finish off with a few lengths in the heated outdoor pool.

Enjoy innovative Mediterranean cuisine in the Il Becco restaurant, either in the candlelit dining room or in the charming courtyard, before enjoying a cocktail in the cosy Fifty Mils.

introduction.small: Classic luxury and impeccable service from one of the city's legendary addresses.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The St. Regis: an extraordinary hotel

paragraphs.text:
Beautifully located on the famous Paseo de la Reforma, in a building made entirely of glass and steel, the St. Regis is one of the most prestigious addresses in Mexico City.

Designed by New York design firm Yabu Pushelberg, the hotel is wrapped in shades of cream, sage, and purple, and interior decorated with superb works of art. The 189 spacious rooms and suites have spectacular views over Chapultepec Park and Castle and Popocatépetl volcano.

Enjoy a cocktail at the King Cole bar before dining at the elegant Diana restaurant. Have a relaxing treatment at the luxurious Remède Spa with its two Jacuzzis and an indoor pool that seems to literally float in the air.

content.title: El Japonez: Mexico City's temple of trendiness

introduction.small: You can find Japanese-Mexican fusion cuisine served at these three fashionable restaurants.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: El Japonez: Mexico City's temple of trendiness

paragraphs.text:
El Japonez Polanco serves fresh and tasty Japanese dishes with Mexican influences. At all six restaurants, in Condesa, Oasis, Interlomas, Polanco, Malacar and Santa Fe, the dining rooms are in wood and glass, with vertical gardens and natural light.

Discover the taquito shiso salmòn, salmon fillet wrapped in shiso leaves filled with fish eggs, yuzu kosho (mix of Japanese yuzu and hot pepper) and fried wontons, the Chinese ravioli. Dine at teppanyaki tables and try tacos by the same name (teppanyaki in Japanese means 'grilled on an iron plate') with beef, tuna, shrimp or duck. And do try the simply exquisite cocktails.

content.title: Watch a lucha libre match at Arena Mexico

introduction.small: A true tradition, Mexican wrestling is an art that is an integral part of popular culture.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Watch a lucha libre match at Arena Mexico

paragraphs.text:
If you are lucky enough to be in Mexico City on a Tuesday or a Friday, don't miss the fights organised at Arena Mexico. You won't be disappointed by the spectacle that takes place in the ring, nor the incredible excitement in the arena. Wrestling is family entertainment in Mexico. They are major events for Mexicans of all stripes and social classes who can number up to 15,000 fans a night.

Every time a masked and costumed luchador makes his entrance it is a big show with music, smoke, and ring card girls. The style of lucha libre (literally,'free fight' in Spanish) is spectacularly acrobatic with wrestlers performing endless spins, flips, leaps, holds, and throws.

content.title: Take a boat to Xochimilco

introduction.small: South of the city, discover the slow pace of multi-coloured boats on quiet canals.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Take a boat to Xochimilco

paragraphs.text:
A visit to the floating gardens of Xochimilco, which means ‘flower gardens', is a trip back in time to when this extended system of canals was the agricultural centre of Teotihuacan civilisation.

These marshes, unsuitable for traditional agriculture, pushed the inhabitants to build floating gardens to grow their crops. The chinampas, artificial islands created out of reeds or corn stove rover on which leaves and soil were laid, are now a UNESCO World Heritage Site. Rent a colourful flat-bottomed boat (trajinera) to explore the flowery floating gardens of the 'Venice of Mexico' to the sound of mariachi music. Look for merchants travelling in small boats who sell everything.

As Sundays are usually crowded, come on weekdays to visit the site. Board the Light Rail in Mexico City; you will be in Xochimilco in about 90 minutes.

content.title: Evening on the Plaza Garibaldi

introduction.small: An old square where the history of Mexico is re-enacted every night, accompanied by traditional musicians.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Evening on the Plaza Garibaldi

paragraphs.text:
From 5:00 p.m. onward, the Plaza Garibaldi is taken over by mariachi bands, musicians playing trumpets, violins, guitars, (vihuela and guitarron) typical of Mexican folklore. It is also here that unfaithful husbands come with their future wives, to offer love songs to their beloved.

Sit at a table at Tenampa, a famous cantina, and order a piña colada or a tequila (Plaza Garibaldi is the only square in Mexico where one is allowed to drink alcohol). The musicians, wearing the operetta costumes popularised in the movies, play at music contests and at wedding parties. Request a private serenade from them: the price of the song depends on the size of the orchestra.

content.title: Discover the Palacio de Bellas Artes

introduction.small: The largest centre for Mexican arts and folkloric ballet.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Discover the Palacio de Bellas Artes

paragraphs.text:
An impressive building designed in 1901 by Italian architect Adamo Boari, which took several architects the next 30 years to build, the Palacio de Bellas Artes is unique in its mix of styles

Enjoy the extravagant Art Nouveau exterior in Carrara marble topped by a striking and colourful dome. Admire the spectacular Art Deco interior with circular Tiffany stained glass and frescoes by Diego Rivera, José Clemente Orozco, David Alfaro Siqueiros, Rufino Tamayo, and Jorge González Camarena, five of Mexico's greatest painters. Used for opera, classical music, and dance, the Palace of Fine Arts also houses the National Fine Arts Museum and the Museum of the Book

It now welcomes more than 1.5 million visitors a year and has definitely established itself as the true pillar of artistic and cultural creation in the country.

content.title: See a theatre piece at UNAM

introduction.small: One of the most famous Spanish-speaking universities in the world, where you can also see alternative theatre.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: See a theatre piece at UNAM

paragraphs.text:
Even before being declared a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 2007, the National Autonomous University of Mexico (UNAM), whose current campus was built between 1950 and 1954, was already the pride of the country.

Established in 1910, it is the second oldest public university in America after that of Santo Domingo, and some of the most influential scientists, artists, and people in the world of politics have studied here. The campus houses the largest educational institution in the country as well as beautiful works by Mexican muralists like Diego Riviera and David Alfaro Siqueiros. Today you will also find several large gardens, one of which includes a cultural space with prominent sculptures, a museum of contemporary art, a football stadium, cinemas, and a theatre.

Look on the university's website to find out about what plays are scheduled. They are always true artistic discoveries.

content.title: A day-trip to Teotihuacán

introduction.small: Teotihuacán is undoubtedly one of the most important pre-Hispanic sites in Mexico.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: A day-trip to Teotihuacán

paragraphs.text:
Located about 50 kilometres north of Mexico City, Teotihuacán is, if you are passionate about history and anthropology, an ideal destination to spend the day.

This Aztec city would have numbered more than 200,000 inhabitants at its peak around the year 450, making it one of the largest cities in the world at the time. The name, which means ‘inhabited place of the gods', was given by the Aztecs for whom this city was a sacred place, even though they had already abandoned it for several centuries when their civilisation began to develop.

The main road through the centre of Teotihuacan is called the 'Path of the Dead' (Calzada de los Muertos). It is almost 2.5-kilometre long and about 40 metres wide. Along it, you can admire many impressive monuments, such as the Pyramid of the Sun, which rises to more than 60 metres in height. Though the climb to the top is difficult, it has an incomparable panorama. Also visit the Pyramid of the Moon, the Temple of Quetzalcoatl and the Palace of Quetzalpápalotl.

content.title: Plaza de la Constitutión: witness to great moments in history

introduction.small: This square in the centre of Old Mexico City is one of the most beautiful in the world.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Plaza de la Constitutión: witness to great moments in history

paragraphs.text:
Near the Templo Mayor, Plaza de la Constitution was built on the ruins of Tenochtitlan, the capital of the Aztec empire destroyed by the conquistadors, along with its stone pyramids. Nearby are the Metropolitan Cathedral and the seat of local executive power, as well as many commercial and administrative buildings, and hotels, plus street vendors and folk dance groups.

A major attraction of Mexico City, the Plaza of the Constitution has been the privileged onlooker of great moments in Mexican history for centuries. This is where union demonstrations, cultural events, and political ceremonies take place. Commonly known as ‘El Zócalo' (‘the base' in Spanish), the square owes its nickname to the base of a monument that was supposed to stand in the middle to celebrate Mexican independence, but which was never completed.

content.title: Try Mexican street food

introduction.small: Enjoy tacos, torta, and chorizo quesadillas in street stalls, and discover real local cuisine.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Try Mexican street food

paragraphs.text:
There are thousands of taquerias (taco restaurants) in Mexico City. They serve tamales, quesadillas, elotes (corn on the cob cooked over a wood fire), chapulines (roasted grasshoppers), and other very local specialities.

When you come to Mexico City you must try these. Many of these gourmet food stands are found in markets such as the Mercado de Allende, in the Coyoacán neighbourhood, where you will be overwhelmed by all the fresh juices, typical sandwiches, traditional churros, and other hot dishes. Taco lovers must try tacos al pastor (stuffed with pineapple and pork) as a change from classic recipes with beef, chicken, or fish. Never fear, taquerias always serve surprising, ultra-fresh cuisine: the proof is in the long queues where tourists and people finishing their workday mingle with labourers, families, and hipsters.

Keep your eye out for taquerias with the longest queues, as they are often the best. Please note, taquerias open at dawn and close when they've run out of food. Go early.

content.title: Go shopping in Polanco

introduction.small: Stroll in this trendy area north of Chapultepec Park, which is teeming with brand boutiques, art galleries, and restaurants.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Go shopping in Polanco

paragraphs.text:
Discover Mexican and international fashion designers at the Frattina boutique, a mecca for the knowledgeable and stylish shopper. At Galeria Mexicana de Diseño, they have been promoting design for more than 20 years.

Go through this ultra-modern urban space to discover exceptional collections of jewellery, textiles, and furniture. For household items that combine Mexican craftsmanship and modern design, Artefacto is your shop of choice. The Art Deco districts of Condesa and Roma are the perfect destinations for authentic contemporary works of art, decorative objects, or a new wardrobe. Stop at Chic by Accident, a 1920s mansion that has been converted into an exceptional exhibition hall.

Finally, NaCo Miscelánea is famous for its street-wear collections and printed T-shirts, an absolute must in Mexico City.

content.title: Palacio National: ancient palace of Spanish viceroys

introduction.small: Built on the site of the palace of the Aztec emperor, Montezuma, this building is the largest in Mexico.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Palacio National: ancient palace of Spanish viceroys

paragraphs.text:
The 200-metre-long Palacio was the palace of the viceroys of Spain and the presidents of the Republic in the 19th century. In 1821, in the wake of the Mexico's independence, it was called the National Palace.

Every September 15th of the year, at 11:00 p.m. sharp, the president proclaims,'El Grito!', which is Mexico's slogan of Independence, to which the crowd responds by shouting 'Viva México!' On the main staircase and walls of the second floor are superb wall frescoes by Diego Rivera, Frida Kahlo's husband. They tell the history of Mexico from 1531 to 1930.

Sign up for a guided tour, and do not forget to bring your passport in order to be admitted into the palace. And check information ahead of time, as there aren't tours every day.

content.title: Climb to the top of the Torre Latinoamericana

introduction.small: Admire this splendid city from the 43rd floor of the Torre Latinoamericana.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Climb to the top of the Torre Latinoamericana

paragraphs.text:
Directly across the street from the Palacio de Bellas Artes is the Torre Latinoamericana skyscraper. Forty-four storeys high, it dominates the impressive Mexican megalopolis, the third largest urban area in the world, with 20 million inhabitants. When it was completed in 1956, the Latin American Tower was the tallest building in Mexico, and remained so until 1984, when the Torre WTC, taller by 24 metres, was finished.

The tower was built to house the headquarters of Latinoamericana Seguros, an insurance company that gave its name to the building during the economic boom of the post-war period, between the late 1940s and mid-1960s. On the 43rd floor, where its platform is easily accessible, you can enjoy one of Mexico City's most beautiful observation decks.

content.title: Be amazed at the San Juan Market

introduction.small: The city's biggest market at its historic core.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Be amazed at the San Juan Market

paragraphs.text:
The market of San Juan, whose official name is ‘Ernesto Pugibet Market', has been in the heart of Mexico City for more than 150 years.

Originally very small in size, it has become the favourite meeting spot for gourmets in search of fine food and exotic ingredients, especially meats. You can find anything here: game, wild boar, quail, ducks, fish, and seafood.Check out La Jersey, one of the most popular stalls. While Perla and Celso fix your sandwich, enjoy some red wine and cheese samples. Next door, there is an indoor market with two floors selling pottery, tablecloths, and local crafts.

The San Juan Market is open Monday to Sunday, from 7 a.m. to 5 p.m.

content.title: Get a massage in Mexico

introduction.small: Take a break and enjoy a soothing moment at the W's Away Spa, the Qi Urban Spa, or the Four Seasons Spa.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Get a massage in Mexico

paragraphs.text:
The Away Spa in the W Hotel is a bubble of calm and quiet in the middle of all the madness that is Mexico City. The sleek interiors, bright colours, and Zen atmosphere are complemented by exceptional views of the city.

Relax with a ‘Temazcal' traditional treatment or sweat it out in the steam room before diving into the relaxation pool or treating yourself to a fantastic body treatment. In the trendy Condesa district is Qi Urban Spa, a contemporary sanctuary of blonde wood and design furniture that offers yoga, meditation, and a wide range of treatments. This hyped urban retreat regularly attracts the city's celebrities.

Indulge in a traditional Punta Mita massage before diving into the relaxation pool or sunbathing on the sublime terrace. For an elegant and refined spa, choose the Four Seasons Spa with its beautiful outdoor pool, Jacuzzi, fitness rooms, sauna, and customised beauty treatments.

content.title: Our Lady of Guadalupe: dedicated to the Virgin of Guadalupe

introduction.small: In the north of the city, the basilica is one of the most visited churches in the world.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Our Lady of Guadalupe: dedicated to the Virgin of Guadalupe

paragraphs.text:
With more than 20 million pilgrims a year, the Basilica of Our Lady of Guadalupe is the most visited monument in the Catholic world after Vatican City. It is also an important pilgrimage site for millions of Mexicans who go there on the day of the Virgin of Guadalupe (December 12). The circular basilica contains a single relic dating from the 16th century: a cloak purportedly belonging to the Virgin Mary.

According to legend, it belonged to St. Juan Diego, a peasant to whom the Virgin appeared near the site of the basilica on Tepeyac hill, north of Mexico City. Inaugurated in 1976, in lieu of a former church built between the 16th and 17th centuries that was close to collapse, the basilica is usually full of people all the time. If you do not want to wait too long, it's best to visit in the early morning or just before closing time.

content.title: Spend a night in Acapulco

introduction.small: Discover the most beautiful bays in the world, and enjoy the Mexican sun.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Spend a night in Acapulco

paragraphs.text:
It is a good idea to escape from Mexico City to explore one of the finest areas in the country. Just 368 km from the capital (4 hours by car or 1 hour by plane) is Acapulco Bay, considered the “queen of Mexican beaches”.

The city, which is one of the top destinations in the country, welcomes thousands of visitors throughout the year. This energetic city is also famous for its death divers, clavadistas, who launch themselves off the 45-metre-high cliffs of Quebrada to great peril.

You can play golf on the famous Tres Vidas golf course, go shopping, do some sport fishing, and explore lagoons, jungle, islands, and estuaries in the year-round sunshine. Book a room at Boca Chica in the Caleta area. A mythical hotel of the 1950s, now restored, it is one of the top addresses in Acapulco.

content.title: The National Museum of Anthropology: one of the world's finest

introduction.small: Safeguarding the rich cultural history of Mexico, the Museum of Anthropology possesses the largest collection of Mesoamerican works in the world.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The National Museum of Anthropology: one of the world's finest

paragraphs.text:
Though André Malraux called it ‘the most beautiful museum in the world' when it was inaugurated in 1964, the National Museum of Anthropology has been recently renovated.

It is the perfect place to learn about Mexico's rich culture, from the pre-historic nomadic tribes up to the Spanish conquest. It brings together major works of Mesoamerican civilizations including Mayan, Olme, Toltec, and Aztec, and is the best starting point for any journey in the footsteps of Mexico's ancient civilizations.

Among other wonders, you can admire the famous Sun Stone, the most famous work of Aztec art, also called, incorrectly, the ‘Aztec Calendar'. This museum is a must, and it is a place where you can easily spend an afternoon or a whole day.

content.title: Chapultepec Castle

introduction.small: The former summer residence of the royal family, now a national museum, overlooking Mexico City.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Chapultepec Castle

paragraphs.text:
Unless you take the tourist train, you have to climb to reach Chapultepec Castle, located in the centre of the park of the same name. From up there, away from the bustle and noise of the city, the view is splendid.

The site brings together a museum on the history of Mexico covering the 16th century to the 1917 Declaration of Independence, and the castle of Emperor Maximilian of Hapsburg and Empress Charlotte. A true conservatory of art and history, the castle tells as much about the past of New Spain as the struggle for the independence of Mexico.

Amid the marble stairs and neoclassical apartments, you can admire weapons, coins, costumes, and letters from the Spanish colonial period as well as paintings of epic battles, the official carriages of Benito Juárez and Emperor Maximilian, and sculptures representing the daily life of Mexicans and the history of their country. The gardens are beautiful. Do not hesitate to stop in one of the small restaurants around the castle and order a typical dish.

content.title: Taxco: silver capital of the world

introduction.small: Take a day-trip to Taxco, a village in the mountains near Mexico City, famous for its silver production.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Taxco: silver capital of the world

paragraphs.text:
One hundred and eighty kilometres south of Mexico City, Taxco is perched in the mountains of Guerrero. This town of 40,000 inhabitants has winding cobblestone streets that afford glimpses of charming squares and rooftops.

This city of silver was founded in 1529 by Rodrigo de Castañeda, one of Hernán Cortés's captains. The striking of a silver vein accelerated the city's growth in the 18th century. Discover the city by cable car 175 metres up in the sky. Take it to the Hotel Monte Taxco, hidden in the mountains, north of the town.The city is a paradise for silver jewellery, and home to more than 300 shops solely dedicated to silverware. Take Calle Nacional where the Platería La Mina is or Calle Juárezto get to Plaza Borda.

There is also a splendid craft market on the corner of Cuauhtémoc and Miguel Hidalgo.

content.title: Condesa DF: the place to be

introduction.small: One of the most fashionable design hotels in Mexico City, located in a 1928 neoclassical building.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Condesa DF: the place to be

paragraphs.text:
At Condesa DF, the Mexican architectural firm Higuera & Sanchez have enhanced the elegance of the interior courtyard, while Parisian designer India Mahdavi has affixed her unique style to the hotel.

The 40 rooms feature customised furniture, tropical wood panelling, and handmade ceramic tiles. Moss green walls, vintage printed-cloth chairs, and rounded sofas add a touch of sweetness and nature to this modern atmosphere. After a day of sightseeing, relax in the steam room or treat yourself to a relaxing massage at the luxurious spa.

The El Patio restaurant offers inventive cuisine that fuses Mexican, European and Asian influences. On the hotel roof with its triangular patio is Arriba, a sushi and cocktail bar worthy of Miami Beach.

content.title: Chapultepec Park: another way

introduction.small: An ecological urban area of nearly 850 hectares, this park is a sanctuary from the bustle of the city.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Chapultepec Park: another way

paragraphs.text:
An important natural reserve, this park is also a historic treasure. Explore the first of its three sections, the oldest and most popular, which houses the Museum of Anthropology, the zoo, the Museum of Modern Art and the thermal baths of Montezuma. Casa del Largo is a prominent cultural hangout that puts on free concerts, especially at the weekends.

Every Wednesday evening, tours by bike or small train are organised. It takes you to famous sites as well as little-known nooks. You will walk between the lakes and see sublimely lit monuments and bubbling fountains. A guide and an experienced park warden animate this tour with songs, anecdotes, jokes, and love stories.

These tours take place from November until the end of March.

content.title: CLIMATE AND WEATHER IN Mexico
content.introduction: Mexico City has a temperate climate influenced by its high altitude of 2,250 metres (7,382 feet). Winters (from December to March) are mild and rather dry. Spring (from April to June) is the season with the highest temperatures and summer (from June to September) the rainy season. North-easterly trade winds frequently sweep through the city in February and March.

airports.title: Mexico City Benito Juárez International Airport
airports.description:
Mexico City's International Airport, the largest and busiest in Mexico, and the second busiest in all of Latin America by passenger traffic, is located about 13 kilometres (8 miles) north-east of the city centre.
  • Two terminals:
    • Terminal 1 (Air France)
    • Terminal 2

Getting from the airport to Mexico City and back:
  • By car
    • Accessible via Avenida Frey Servando Teresa de Mier.
    • There are 3 short- and long-term parking facilities at the airport, with a capacity of 5,000 spaces (MXN 22 for 30 minutes, MXN 288 for 1 day).
    • Several car rental companies have counters in the arrivals hall.
  • By rail
    • A Metro station is located next to the airport in Zone A. Take line 5 to reach Mexico City's centre and Pantitlán, where you can change to Line 1. Get off at the Insurgentes station. A single ticket costs MXN 5.
    • AICM Bus line from the airport to the city centre. Leaves from Terminal D. One-way ticket fare is MXN 6.
  • By Metrobús
    • Line 4 connects the airport with San Lázaro station, where you can pick up Line 1 or Line B of the Metro. The fare for this airport service provided by Metrobús is MXN 30 each way and payment must be made in Terminals 1 and 2. Operated from 4:30 a.m. to midnight Monday to Saturday and from 5:00 to midnight on Sunday.
  • By taxi
    • Official 'Sitio 300' taxis (yellow and white, bearing an airplane logo). You can prepay at the “Transportaciòn Terrestre” counter located next to baggage claim. Fares to central Mexico City run about MXN 127.
  • Services: shops, bars and restaurants, free Internet access (Wi-Fi) available in the airport.
  • Telephone: +52 55 2482 2424 / + 52 55 2482 2400
  • Website: https://www.aicm.com.mx/en/

medical.description: See your doctor before you travel. It is also recommended to take out insurance covering medical expenses and repatriation before your trip. Mexico City counts several hospitals and medical institutions, as well as quality medical practitioners and health specialists.

information.title: Vaccinations
information.description:
Visitors arriving from countries where yellow fever is endemic must show proof of yellow fever vaccination, usually documented on an International Certificate of Vaccination or Prophylaxis (ICVP). Obtaining a booster vaccination against diphtheria, tetanus, pertussis and polio is recommended. For more information, contact Air France's international vaccination centre:

  • Address: 38, quai de Jemmapes, 75010 Paris
  • Website: www.vaccinations-airfrance.fr
  • Telephone: +33 (0)1 43 17 22 00
  • To make a vaccination appointment:
    • online (click here)
    • call the centre at +33 (0)1 43 17 22 00

information.title: Effects of high altitude
information.description: The problems that you are likely to face at high altitude depend on your body's ability to adapt to changes in atmospheric conditions. If you have heart disease or a respiratory disorder, you should consult with your doctor before visiting Mexico City. All visitors should be aware that an adaptation period is often necessary.

information.title: Water
information.description: Tap water is not safe to drink. Favour bottled mineral water instead.

essentialPhrases.title: Essential phrases
essentialPhrases.introduction: Here are a few basic Spanish phrases that will make your stay in Mexico City a little easier:
phrases: Hello / Good morning / Good afternoon: ¡ Buenos días ! (morning) / ¡ Buenas tardes ! (afternoon)
What time is it ?: ¿ Que hora es ?

Sorry: Disculpe (to say sorry)
Excuse me: Con permiso (to get past) / ¡ Por favor ! (to get attention).
How much is (…)?: ¿ Cuál es el precio de (…) ? /¿ Cuánto es ?
Where can I find (…)?: ¿ Dónde puedo encontrar (…) ?
Where can I buy (…)?: ¿ Dónde puedo comprar (…) ?

localCalendar.title: FESTIVALS, HOLIDAYS AND OTHER ANNUAL EVENTS IN Mexico
localCalendar.description: There are a number of festivals, holidays and other events celebrated in Mexico City each year. The main ones are listed below.

events.title: January 6: Epiphany (Día de los Santos Reyes, celebrated nationwide)
events.description: For the feast of the three kings, Mexicans get together with their families to share the rosca de reyes, a sweetbread baked in the shape of an oval ring, with a plastic figure of the baby Jesus concealed inside.

events.title: May 5: Anniversary of the Battle of Puebla (Cinco de Mayo, national holiday)
events.description: Celebrated as a holiday throughout Mexico, commemorating the victory of the Mexican militia over the forces of Napoleon III in 1862.

events.title: July 16: Our Lady of Mount Carmel (celebrated nationwide)
events.description: The liturgical feast of Our Lady of Mount Carmel is celebrated across Mexico with fairs, dances and stage shows.

events.title: September 16: Independence Day (Grito de Dolores, national holiday)
events.description: This celebration commemorates the grito, a call to sedition issued by Manuel Hidalgo y Costilla, a Roman Catholic priest from the small town of Dolores, on this day in 1810. Each year on the night of September 15, the Mexican president rings the bell of the National Palace in Mexico City and delivers a speech from its balcony. When he waves the nation's tricoloured flag, thousands of spectators cry out in unison, “Viva Mexico!”

events.title: November 1- 2: All Saints' Day and All Souls' Day (Días de los Muertos, celebrated nationwide)
events.description: With festivities that combine Christian and native traditions, this two-day celebration is a very important event for the Mexican people. They evoke and pay tribute to the memory of their dearly departed with a festive celebration through prayer, song, music and dance.

events.title: December 12: Our Lady of Guadalupe (national holiday)
events.description: Celebration of Mexico's patron saint. Festivities throughout Mexico City and around the country include shows, dancing, concerts etc.

administrativeProcedures.title: Entry requirements for Mexico
administrativeProcedures.description:
As a French citizen, you do not need to obtain a visa if you will be visiting Mexico as a tourist for less than 180 days. However, your passport must be valid for the entire period of your stay and you must be in possession of an onward or return ticket.

goodToKnow.tips:
Tipping
Leaving a tip, called a “propina”, is expected in Mexico City. In bars and restaurants, it is customary to tip between 10 and 15% of the bill. However, before leaving a tip, check the bill to make sure that a gratuity or service charge is not already included.
